discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The divisibility test for 9 is applicable here (which is glaringly obvious since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1 \leq 9 \leq 15 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"). "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
The total sum of the digits will be equal to some multiple of 9. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1 \times ( 1 + 8 + a ) + 2 \times ( 3 + 6 + 7) + 4 \times 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is  a multiple of 9. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
This is equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 41 + a "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0 \leq a \leq 9 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", hence we must have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a = 4 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to give "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 41 + 4 = 45 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" as the multiple of 9."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"orderedList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"15!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \lfloor \frac{15}{3} \rfloor + \lfloor \frac{15}{3^2} \rfloor = 5 + 1 = 6 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" factors of 3, so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"15!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a multiple of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3^6 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". This approach shows us that even "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 6!, 7!, 8! "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are multiples of 9 even though 9 doesn't appear in the expanded multiplication."}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note: If the digit sum without "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a multiple of 9, then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" could only be 0 or 9. We will need to do more work."}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I like that question! "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Eric's approach would work better for this problem, as we will always get just 1 answer. If more digits were hidden, then we will need more tests.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"15!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lfloor \frac{15}{2} \rfloor + \lfloor \frac{15}{2^2} \rfloor + \lfloor \frac{15}{2^3} \rfloor = 7 + 3 + 1 = 11"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" factors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". You can be sure that the last n digits is divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"; for example "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a368000"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a368"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", if the double possibility of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" arises.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Similar to Saya Suka's solution, but with 11."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let each digits in 130767a368000 have indexes, where the first digit (1) has an index of 1, the second digit (3) has an index of 2, and etc."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The divisibility test for 11 is that the sum of all the digits with even indexes differ from the sum of all the digits with odd indexes by a multiple of 11 
(including 0)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Sum of digits with odd digits: 
1 + 0  + 6 + a + 6 + 0 + 0 = 13 + a
Sum of digits with even digits: 
3 + 7 + 7 + 3 + 8 + 0 = 28"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"13 + a = 28 + 11n "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
a= 15 + 11n "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Since a is a digit,  0<= a <= 9. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Thus, n = -1 and a = 4"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Nice! The benefit of using the rule of 11 is that we're guaranteed a unique answer no matter which digit is hidden (assuming that all the other digits are correct).

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I don't think it's an overkill because of how simple the rule is. If we tried to apply divisibility by 17 which doesn't have a real simple use, then that would be an overkill.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            11 might be a bit overkill for this problem, but is the best method in this "},{"type":"text","text":"variation","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":"!

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 15 followers question
#15 Measure your Calibre
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Choose the correct Option","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I) If the linear momentum of a body is conserved then angular momentum is conserved about a point."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"II) If the angular momentum of a body is conserved about a point then the linear momentum is conserved."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Other problems: "},{"type":"text","text":"Check your Calibre","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Simple linear momentum is conserved when a particle moves in a straight line so angular momentum will be conserved about any point.
But now consider circular motion so angular momentum will be conserved but linear momentum will change its direction every time"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Both the statements are wrong ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider a smooth rod placed on a horizontal surface."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If we apply forces at its two ends in same direction linear momentum wont be conserved but angular momentum will be conserved."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Similarly if they are applied in opposite directions then angular momentum wont be conserved but linear momentum will be conserved"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: #16 Measure your Calibre
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"All the leters of the word SURITI are arranged in a dictionary. Find the rank of the word.
If rank is coming out "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"D"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"D+60 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Details and Assumptions","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here rank means at what number the word comes in the dictionary made of all possible arrangements the letters of that particular word."}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Like a normal dictionary, the words are alphabetized from A to Z. "}]}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Other problems: "},{"type":"text","text":"Check your Calibre","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]}]}]}

title: 15 points

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If we want to choose three points, we can do it
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\binom{15}{3}=\dfrac{15*14*13}{1*2*3}=455"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
ways. The three points always define a triangle, except they are on the same line. There are three lines, and there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" points in each of them. Since three points can't be on two lines at the same moment, from the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"455"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3*\binom{6}{3}=3*\dfrac{6*5*4}{1*2*3}=60"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
ways aren't make solutions. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore the answer is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"455-60=\boxed{395}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lfloor \left| e^A \right| \rfloor = \lfloor e^{1+6+11+0} \rfloor "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which by calculator computation is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \boxed { 65659969. }  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"
